title: How to interpret Godel's incompleteness theorem - Quora

response.answer_text: You can interpret it in computer science. It says that any consistent machine is unable to prove some (true) assertion (notably about itself. The machine is able to prove their own theorem (this was seen and announced by Gödel, but proved by Hilbert and Bernays later, and by Löb). You can see this as a theorem in neoplatonist machine theology, and indeed, the theory of matter made by the neoplatonist is vindicated by logic, as we found quantum logic for the behaviour of the machine’s observable, when defined in the neoplatonist self-referential mode of the (sound, or just consistent) machine. This shows that for any machine introspecting itself the machine is able to distinguish qualia and quanta, and that eventually physics is reduced to a statistic on the many computations (realised in arithmetic. We know (or should know) that elementary arithmetic emulate all computations since the 1930s. So, Gödel’s incompleteness can be seen as the first theorem in exact neoplatonician mechanist theory of mind and matter. It is at the least a reminder that science has not yet decided between the Platonic and the Aristotelian conception of reality. I work on this since long and can give references if asked. Contrary to a widespread misconception, Gödel’s incompleteness is a good new for the mechanist theory of mind. Note also that incompleteness can be proved very easily from the Church-Turing thesis in computability theory, using just one diagonalization. Gödel’s technic have been elaborated by Church and Kleene (and foreseen by Emil Post). Post and Kleene are at the origin of recursion or computability theory, making such incompleteness result very important in theoretical computer science. The whole logic of provability of the “rich machine” (Turing universal + enough induction axioms) has been axiomatised in the logic modal G and G* through two fundamental theorem by Solovay in 1976. G forlmibes the part which is justifiable by the machine, and G* formalise the true part, including the corona of the true but non provable part, showing it accessible by the introspecting machine, and laking the machine aware that she knows more than what she can justifie, and this can be used to develop a machine’s theory of its own qualia. In fact Gödel’s incompleteness enforced the epistemic nuances that Theatetus used in its theory of knowledge (in Plato). Indeed, with p an arbitrary sigma_1 (partial computable) sentences, f = false, and “[]” interpreted by “the machine proves”, we have: G* proves p <-> []p <-> ([]p & p) <-> ([]p & ~[]f) <-> ([]p & ~[]f & p), but G does not prove most of them, and this attached an intuitionist knower, and a quantum observer, canonically to any self-referentially correct machine.

Well, I have never dealt with Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorems, so I write now some my thoughts related to them. I have been always admiring Gödel’s technique leading to prove Gödel’s First Incompleteness Theorem. An interesting fact is that Gödel never proved Gödel’s Second Incompleteness Theorem. He proved Gödel's First Incompleteness Theorem. The first full proof of the Gödel's Second Incompleteness Theorem was published in the book: David Hilbert and Paul Bernays, "Grundlagen der Mathematik", vol. 2, in 1939 (for e.g.: Roman Murawski, "Recursive Functions and Metamathematics", Springer Dordrecht 1999). I would like also to inform you about the paper: T. J. Stępień, Ł. T. Stępień, „On the Consistency of the Arithmetic System”, Journal of Mathematics and System Science, vol. 7, 43 (2017), arXiv:1803.11072 , where a proof of the consistency of the Arithmetic System was published (this proof had been done within this Arithmetic System); the abstract of this paper: T. J. Stepien and L. T. Stepien, "On the consistency of Peano's Arithmetic System" , The Bulletin of Symbolic Logic , vol. 16, No. 1, 132 (2010). The Bulletin of Symbolic Logic .

It says that any axiomatic-based mathematical system, at least as complex as arithmetic, will not be complete and may even be inconsistent. The first theorem, Incompleteness, says that these mathematical systems (basically all up to set theory) will not be able to demonstrate all its truths within the system. For that, it’s necessary to asume more axioms, that is, go to another more complex level, like algebra or calculus, which they in themselves will not be able to prove all their own truths. You may be seeing something that is obviously true, but cannot be proven within the system. The second theorem, which I understand is a corollary of the first, is even worse. It says that any such mathematical system cannot prove its own consistency. For that it needs to recur to a more complete system. This case is worse, because it says that, given the potential inconsistency of mathematical systems, there’s a chance a contradiction may be proven, like two theorems that prove opposite truths.

Gödel’s theorems applies to *formal systems* (please, note: formal systems), and they say that no formal system satisfy the following properties at once: For every sentence A formulated in the language of the system (note: you need to have a well defined notion of sentences, something you don’t have in natural languages), the system proves either A or ~A, the negation of A.The system does not prove (note: you need a clear definition of what means “to prove”) both a sentence A and its negation, ~A.It is an *effective* theory, that is, we can know in an effective way (OK, say by a computer program) if some sentence of the well stated language of the theory is or not an axiom of the system.it is strong enough to express Robinson’s arithmetic.So, the theorem does not apply to the Bible, nor to the human consciousness, nor to nothing that is not a recursive formal system able to cope with (at least) Robinson’s arithmetic.

Nowadays, one of my favorite pastimes is not interpreting Gödel’s incompleteness theorems. Seriously, I really enjoy it. I could spend hours not interpreting one of the theorems, and on the best days – which, honestly, are most days – I interpret neither the first nor the second. Reading other people’s interpretations, paraphrases, exegeses, extrapolations, exaggerations and transubstantiations has cost me dearly. I lost time, hair and romantic partners – I confess, there were some hearty laughs, but bitter ones, tinged with despair. I’d rather not experience it again. I am, in fact, happy to share what Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorems actually say. This, too, is an excellent pastime, almost on par with not interpreting them. Here is one such attempt, right here on Quora. I should dig up a talk I once gave, at the closing ceremony of the Berkeley Math Circle. See also this. And this. Or this. There’s more, I’m quite sure. Really, I love talking about the theorems, but ”interpreting” them is something I learned to deeply resent.

Basically, it states that any formal logical system that’s consistent (i.e., doesn’t prove false statements), as well as “sufficiently complex” (i.e., able to talk about integer arithmetic in a certain way that’s well-known to mathematicians), will always contain true statements that cannot be proven within that system — that’s the sense in which they are incomplete. It came as quite a disappointment when Godel announced it, since it claimed that formal logical systems are inherently limited in their scope of application.

I took a class in “Philosophical Significance of Goedel’s Theorem” at Harvard in the early 80s. We spent almost the entire class working through the details of the theorem and its extensions. At the end, someone asked the instructor (a philosophy professor), “When are we going to learn about its philosophical significance.” The instructor replied, “If you understand the math, you’ll see it it has no philosophical significance.”

How do you interpret Godel's incompleteness theorem? It says, approximately, that in any axiomatic system that models the basic arithmetic of the integers, there will be true statements within that system that cannot be proved within the system. I am not an expert on this, so hope for other answers.
